G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Under **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, the Court may modify a custody order “upon a showing that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and that the modification is necessary in the best interests of the children.”

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the subject matter and parties under G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and related case law (see *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)).

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: The Court is authorized under **G.L. c. 215, § 6** to grant such equitable relief as may be necessary for the welfare of the children.

*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over the subject matter and parties under G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and related case law (see *Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981)).
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns the standards and findings required for an initial custody determination in a divorce proceeding, focusing on the best interests and welfare of the child under G.L. c. 208, § 31. It does not discuss continuing jurisdiction, G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, or the court’s ongoing authority over the subject matter or parties. Thus, it does not provide authority for the continuing-jurisdiction proposition for which it is cited.
*Bouchard v. Bouchard*, 12 Mass. App. Ct.relevant_excerpt: That portion of the judgment granting custody to the wife is reversed. The case is remanded to the Probate Court solely on that issue. The judge’s subsidiary findings should state all the relevant factors on which his general conclusion is based. Pending such further hearing and until the entry of any new order and judgment by the Probate Court, the stay ordered by the single justice of this court shall remain in full force and effect.

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Since the entry of the March 15, 2022 custody order, there has been a **material and substantial change in circumstances** affecting the welfare and best interests of the minor children, as defined by **G.L. c. 208, § 28**, and *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: Mason v. Coleman is a removal/relocation case interpreting G.L. c. 208, § 30 and articulating the ‘best interests of the child’ standard when parents share joint physical custody. It does not address the separate threshold requirement under G.L. c. 208, § 28 that there be a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ to modify an existing custody order. Using Mason as authority for the existence or definition of such a material and substantial change under § 28 misstates the holding and context of the decision.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents… shall not… be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth… without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: This demonstrates that the current arrangement is causing instability and emotional harm, circumstances that Mass. courts deem significant in modification proceedings (*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde is a divorce/custody and property division case, not a post-judgment modification case. While it discusses emotional conflict between the parents and its impact on what custody arrangement is in the children’s best interests, it does not address modification standards or treat existing instability/emotional harm as a basis to modify a prior custody or support order. Using Rolde as authority on what ‘Mass. courts deem significant in modification proceedings’ therefore overreads the case’s holding and context.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The judge concluded that ‘joint custody or shared responsibility is an invitation to continued warfare and conflict.’ … The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..proposition: This demonstrates that the current arrangement is causing instability and emotional harm, circumstances that Mass. courts deem significant in modification proceedings (*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981); *Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App. Ct. 239 (2015)).
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..support_reasoning: The proposition is that instability and emotional harm to the child are circumstances Massachusetts courts deem significant in custody/modification-type determinations. Schechter repeatedly emphasizes the emotional harm to the child from exposure to domestic violence and from the father’s conduct, and treats that harm and the need for stability as central to the best-interests analysis for custody, visitation, and removal. Although Schechter is not itself a post-judgment modification case, its reasoning clearly affirms that emotional harm and instability are weighty, outcome-determinative factors in parenting decisions under Massachusetts law.
*Schechter v. Schechter*, 88 Mass. App..relevant_excerpt: “The judge’s decision to suspend visitation for one year is also supported by his extensive findings that over the course of their relationship, the father had engaged in physical, emotional, and financial abuse of the mother, and, in his interactions with the child, had damaged the mother’s relationship with the child. See G. L. c. 208, § 31A. Children who experience domestic violence, whether as direct witnesses or indirectly as members of the household in which violence occurs, ‘suffer deep and profound harms’… the evidence in the record does not rebut the judge’s factual determinations illustrating the point.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..proposition: The existing provisions for joint legal custody, though entered in good faith, are no longer serving the children's best interests because Defendant’s conduct has impeded cooperative decision-making, contrary to the standards articulated in *Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 (1985).
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion in Yannas discusses joint legal custody only to define it under G.L. c. 208, § 31 and to reject any presumption favoring joint physical custody. It does not address modification or termination of joint legal custody based on one parent’s obstructive conduct or inability to cooperate. The case therefore does not articulate standards about when joint legal custody is no longer in the child’s best interests due to impaired cooperative decision-making, so it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
*Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas*, 395 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The judge did award joint or shared legal custody, which G. L. c. 208, § 31 (1984 ed.), defines as ‘a continued mutual responsibility and involvement by both parents in decisions regarding the child’s welfare in matters of education, medical care, emotional, moral and religious development.’ As we have said, he awarded physical custody, or possession of the children, to the wife. We reject the husband’s assertion that the law of the Commonwealth favors or should presumptively favor joint physical custody.”

*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.proposition: The pattern of non-cooperation constitutes a material change in circumstances under *Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146 (2015), which held that persistent interference with a co-parent’s custodial relationship can justify modification.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.support_reasoning: The opinion in Murray v. Super is a removal and child-support modification case. It applies the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal test and discusses child support, but it does not address modification of custody based on a parent’s non-cooperation or interference with the other parent’s custodial relationship, nor does it treat such interference as a material change in circumstances. The claimed proposition about ‘persistent interference’ justifying modification is not discussed or established anywhere in this decision.
*Murray v. Super*, 87 Mass. App. Ct. 146.relevant_excerpt: “In support of his complaint for modification, the father alleged as a material and substantial change of circumstances the mother’s remarriage. At the time of the modification trial, the judge found that the father’s income had modestly increased, and that the mother’s income remained at zero. The judge further found, however, that the mother now receives estimated contributions from her new husband… Based on those changes… the judge reduced the father’s child support obligation….”

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2.proposition: The children’s best interests and welfare are paramount to this determination (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003); *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly situates its analysis in the longstanding Massachusetts rule that, in custody matters, the ‘best interests of the child’—described as the welfare and interests of the child—are the paramount concern. The court traces this principle historically and cites prior cases (including Yannas and Surrender of Minor Children) for the proposition that the child’s welfare is the paramount issue in custody determinations. Thus, it directly supports the statement that the children’s best interests and welfare are paramount to the determination.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962), quoting Erickson v. Raspperry, 320 Mass. 333, 335 (1946) (‘most fundamental [principle] is that the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.proposition: The children’s best interests and welfare are paramount to this determination (*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003); *Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)).
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly frames the removal decision in terms of the children’s best interests and interprets the governing statute to permit removal when it is in the best interests of the child. The court criticizes the probate judge for focusing too narrowly on visitation and emphasizes that the determination must consider all factors bearing on the children’s welfare, including the well-being of the custodial parent. This aligns with the proposition that the children’s best interests and welfare are paramount in such determinations.
*Hale v. Hale*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, … have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child. … We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.proposition: Plaintiff has maintained a stable home environment, continued the children’s schooling and extracurricular participation, and communicated consistently regarding their health and education, consistent with the standards established in *Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on domestic violence, its impact on children, and the need for explicit findings about that impact in custody determinations. It does not set or discuss any standard about a custodial parent maintaining a stable home, continuity of schooling and extracurricular activities, or consistent communication about health and education. While it notes that the father was involved with the child’s schooling and activities, that is descriptive fact, not a legal standard or holding establishing the proposition claimed.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 (1996.relevant_excerpt: “The judge was also moved by the fact that the boy appeared to be doing very well in his school work and that the father takes a great interest in his activities, meeting regularly with the boy’s teachers.”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The current conflict has impaired the children’s emotional wellbeing, their sense of security in transitions, and their trust in both parents—factors heavily weighted in modification analysis (*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986)).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on whether there was a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody and on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal analysis. It does discuss some disruption and transitional behavior in the child but does not analyze or emphasize impairment of emotional wellbeing, sense of security in transitions, or trust in both parents as heavily weighted factors in modification. Those specific psychological-impact considerations are not framed as key or determinative in the modification analysis in this case, so the citation overstates what Rosenthal stands for on that point.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that Caleb ‘[went] through a transition period when temporary joint custody was awarded to the parties and the Mother moved to Rhode Island. At that time, the child had in fact experienced some changes in his behavior, mostly consisting of instances of aggression or passivity.’ … There are, to the contrary, findings that the order denying removal and changing custody from the mother was disruptive to the child.”

*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.proposition: The current conflict has impaired the children’s emotional wellbeing, their sense of security in transitions, and their trust in both parents—factors heavily weighted in modification analysis (*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001); *Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (1986)).
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on parental unfitness and best interests in an initial care and protection / permanent custody context, not on modification, transition issues, or deterioration of children’s trust in both parents. While it notes the older child’s fear of his father and need for an emotionally stable home, it does not frame these findings as part of a modification analysis nor as a nuanced weighing of how current parental conflict is impairing transitions or trust in both parents. Thus it does not provide authority for the specific proposition claimed.
*Custody of Two Minors*, 396 Mass. 610 (.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found that the older child is aggressive and that this characteristic stems from fear. In addition, he found that the child did not view his environment as safe, could not control his impulses, and had a poor self-image. On several occasions, the judge found, the child had expressed either reluctance or unwillingness to visit his parents because of fear of his father. The judge adopted the opinion of the psychologist ... that the son needed an emotionally stable home environment unavailable to him in the home of his parents.”

*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently required a two-part showing for modification: (1) a material change in circumstances and (2) that the proposed modification serves the children's best interests (*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981)).
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.support_reasoning: This concurring opinion in Smith v. McDonald concerns relocation in the context of paternity and statutory interpretation of G.L. c. 209C; it does not set out or apply a two-part standard for modification requiring (1) material change in circumstances and (2) best interests of the child. The discussion is about the mother’s sole legal custody status before adjudication of paternity and the inapplicability of the Yannas ‘real advantage’ removal test, not about modification standards. Thus, it does not provide authority for the claimed two-part showing requirement for modification.
*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010.relevant_excerpt: After paternity was established, the judge was obligated to take as a given that the mother and the child resided 400 miles apart from, and in another State than, the father, and to fashion custody and visitation orders pursuant to the three factors set out in G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), again respecting and not disturbing the mother’s decision to relocate. See Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 843 (2003) ("If the parenting arrangement in which a child has lived is satisfactory and is reasonably capable of preservation, it is ordinarily in the child’s best interests to maintain that arrangement...").

*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.proposition: Massachusetts courts have consistently required a two-part showing for modification: (1) a material change in circumstances and (2) that the proposed modification serves the children's best interests (*Smith v. McDonald*, 458 Mass. 540 (2010); *Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (1981)).
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that to modify a judgment for alimony or child support the petitioner must show a material change in circumstances. It then adds that, in child support cases, the judge must consider the circumstances of the parents and the benefit/needs of the children, but it does not structure this as a required, separate second prong nor as a consistent two-part test. Thus Schuler supports the material-change requirement, but not the specific two-part formulation claimed in the proposition.
*Schuler v. Schuler*, 382 Mass. 366 (198.relevant_excerpt: “To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment. … In determining whether to modify a support or alimony order, a probate judge must weigh all relevant circumstances. … An order for child support may be modified ‘as the circumstances of the parents and the benefit of the children may require.’ G. L. c. 208, § 28… The needs of the children, the financial status of the support provider, and the station in life of the respective parties must all be considered.”
